abstract.p: New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg says City Council Speaker Gifford Miller should not be using public monies and services to campaign for mayor in response to rumors that Miller staff member sent out e-mail soliciting applicants for campaign staff (M)

block.p: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a shot yesterday at a potential political rival, Speaker Gifford Miller of the City Council, saying an e-mail message sent out by Mr. Miller's aide last week indicated that the speaker may be inappropriately using Council resources to begin a campaign for mayor.

Mr. Miller, a Democrat, has been coy about any mayoral aspirations, but a top aide sent out an unauthorized e-mail message soliciting résumés for a new communications director, saying that Mr. Miller ''is preparing to make a run for Mayor in 2005 and we're revamping and reorganizing the office to get ready.''

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a shot yesterday at a potential political rival, Speaker Gifford Miller of the City Council, saying an e-mail message sent out by Mr. Miller's aide last week indicated that the speaker may be inappropriately using Council resources to begin a campaign for mayor.

Mr. Miller, a Democrat, has been coy about any mayoral aspirations, but a top aide sent out an unauthorized e-mail message soliciting résumés for a new communications director, saying that Mr. Miller ''is preparing to make a run for Mayor in 2005 and we're revamping and reorganizing the office to get ready.''
Under the City Charter, public officials are prohibited from using their position for personal gain.
''They may feel that they can use public monies to go and campaign,'' Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. ''I always thought you couldn't do that.''

Gene Russianoff, a senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said yesterday that he did not see a problem with the message. ''It doesn't say that this person will work on government time to promote Mr. Miller's candidacy,'' he said.

But Mr. Bloomberg, who has been criticized for spending his own money to promote a ballot proposal for nonpartisan elections, suggested a double standard. ''The good-government groups, I haven't heard from them yet,'' he said. ''I suspect if I did something like that, they'd be out there screaming.''
Mr. Miller dismissed the comments yesterday. He said he had lost count of the number of times that the mayor's aides had commented on Mr. Bloomberg's political future.

''This is a political job, and to pretend that there's no politics going on smacks a little bit of 'Casablanca,' '' Mr. Miller said, referring to a scene in the movie in which the authorities pretend not to notice gambling in a casino. ''This is a ridiculous, ridiculous nonissue.''
